hobby.message: Is analog photography still worth the risk?
Urban exploration or just drinking underground?
Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Dry enough. Was out under the ducts earlier, routine stuff.
I poke around tunnels—not everyone’s taste.
Harder to get past the hatches tonight. System acting odd since Halden, I guess.
Yeah, dry. I like to walk the underground when it's quiet.
Urban exploring, you could say. Data centers, utility tunnels, off-hours.
System slowed me down tonight—access locked up.
Halden’s death mucked up the badge system, not that I care much.
Makes my hobby more like work lately.
Dry, dark, and a little weird out there.
I dig old tunnels and sealed data rooms, fix what’s busted for fun.
Not many enjoy crawling around the old exchange lines.
Whole system’s been laggy since Halden checked out—extra access headaches lately.
Last night, spent an hour at a locked hatch, waiting on a reset.
Wasn’t the smooth trip I planned, but not dull.
Dry as old server racks out there, thanks for asking.
I like exploring utility tunnels—keeps me from rotting upstairs.
Not just wandering—sometimes I patch up systems just to see if I still can.
Had trouble last night; my badge wouldn’t open the duct hatch, weird error message.
Heard it’s tied to that Oversight guy’s death—system scrambling to keep up.
Spent an hour drinking in the corridor, waiting it out.
Whole city feels like it’s running on backup protocols now.
Dry outside, but the city’s system is stuck in a feedback loop lately.
You know I’m into crawling the old service tunnels and abandoned server bays.
Used to be I could breeze through on my credentials—nobody cared.
Ever since Halden croaked, clearance protocols keep flagging me.
Last night, the hatch treated me like a stranger—never seen response times so bad.
Had to wait for the system to reboot itself, finished half my flask.
That BCI gridlock even affects where I can wander—not just work’s problem now.
Feels like the whole city’s watching itself stall, waiting for a ghost to switch the lights back on.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still get out there from time to time.
Hobby runs into more locked doors lately.
System's been off since Halden died. Lately, things just take longer.
Doesn’t stop me. Just means I pack extra batteries.
Suppose we all adapt, one way or another.
Yeah, I still roam the tunnels some nights.
Used to be the entry hatches recognized me right away.
Ever since Halden died, clearance gets weird.
Random lockouts, delays—I keep it brief when I’m inside now.
City feels tenser these days, even underneath.
Keep my routes simple—don’t stick around.
That’s me—urban exploring’s the only real quiet left around here.
Halden’s death messed with the tunnel access routines.
Had a run-in with a stuck hatch just last week.
System put me in some fallback queue, flagged me for compliance review.
Lost an hour sitting on concrete, waiting my own system out.
Place was emptier than usual—city’s guts are slowing down.
Feels like even the maintenance corridors noticed something’s changed.
Never really stopped—urban tunnels are more interesting than anyone suspects.
Honestly, Halden’s death is making it trickier.
Access codes fail, or the system gets suspicious, even with my ID.
Last time, I spent forty minutes stuck outside a hatch—system flagged me for compliance drift.
Used to be I could wander without tripping alarms or delays; not anymore.
It’s like someone kicked the guts of the city all out of sequence.
We talk about things being automated, but when a cog like Halden goes, you feel it.
Hardest part now is predicting what’ll work on any given night.
Never got tired of those old tunnels—too many secrets left underground.
Built half the backbone down there in the old days—still know every panel by feel.
Since Halden died, fallback systems treat even maintenance badges like a threat.
Spent an hour in the corridor last weekend—hatch refused me over a minor scoring dip.
If you get flagged now, every system piles on: delays, reroutes, cold shoulder from admins.
I’ve started logging detours, just to keep a map of what the system messes up now.
Noticed a lot fewer maintenance logs downtown lately, like people are avoiding the risk.
The air down there’s different—quieter, but twitchy now, like the city’s holding its breath.
Funny—never thought losing one man at the top would unnerve the pipes themselves.
